elements.content: A novel 3,3‘-bipyridine-type linking ligand L (C26H22N4, py-CHN−(CH3)C6H3−(CH3)C6H3−NCH-py), which possesses two terminal pyridyl groups, was prepared by the Schiff-base condensation. In ligand L, the N···N separation between the terminal pyridyl groups is 18.253 Å, with their nitrogen atoms at the meta positions (3,3‘) in a trans manner. A one-dimensional zinc coordination polymer [ZnL(NO3)2] n (1) and a two-dimensional cobalt coordination polymer [CoL1.5(NO3)2] n (2) were prepared from the corresponding metal nitrates and L by solvothermal reactions. In polymer 1, the ligands exhibit a cisoid coordination of the pyridyl nitrogens. Polymer 2 exhibits the structure of α-arsenic whose repeating unit consists of six Co metals and six L ligands to create a 114-membered ring with dimensions of ca. 40.28 × 20.65 Å. Guest-containing cobalt polymers [CoL2(NO3)2]·X (X = benzene (3a) or toluene (3b)) could also be prepared.

In ligand L, the N⋅⋅⋅N separation between the terminal pyridyl groups is 18.253 Å, with their nitrogen atoms at the meta positions (3,3‘) in a trans manner. A one-dimensional zinc coordination polymer [ZnL(NO3)2] n  (1) and a two-dimensional cobalt coordination polymer [CoL1.5(NO3)2] n  (2) were prepared from the corresponding metal nitrates and L by solvothermal reactions. In polymer 1, the ligands exhibit a cisoid coordination of the pyridyl nitrogens. Polymer 2 exhibits the structure of α-arsenic whose repeating unit consists of six Co metals and six L ligands to create a 114-membered ring with dimensions of ca. 40.28 × 20.65 Å. Guest-containing cobalt polymers [CoL2(NO3)2]⋅X (X = benzene (3a) or toluene (3b)) could also be prepared.

In designing these polymers, properties of linking ligands such as various coordination modes, variable lengths, and relative orientation of donor atoms play a fundamental role in determining the structural outcome of target polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers, also known as metal-organic frameworks, are currently in intensive study due to their useful properties applicable to catalysis, chirality, conductivity, luminescence, spin crossover, and porosity. In designing these polymers, properties of linking ligands such as various coordination modes, variable lengths, and relative orientation of donor atoms play a fundamental role in determining the structural outcome of target polymers.

elements.content: 4,4‘-Bipyridine-type bridging ligands have been used extensively for the synthesis of various organic−inorganic networks, as well as pure organic networks. By contrast, 3,3‘-bipyridine-type ligands have been used only a few times in constructing coordination polymers (Chart ). Several types of 3,3‘-bipyridine derivatives are now known:  3,3‘-bipyridine (L1), 1,2-bis(3-pyridyl)ethyne (L2), 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3,5,6-tetrazene (L3), 1,4-bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (L4), 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-3,4-diaza-2,4-hexadiene (L5), 1,2-bis(3-pyridylmethyleneamino)ethane (L6), and N,N‘-bis(3-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-benzenebis(methylamine) (L7). Among them, ligands L4−L7 were prepared by the Schiff-base condensation. It is worth noting that Constable and co-workers recently developed a synthetic route to a new class of dinucleating ligands by functionalizing 3,3‘-bipyridine and its derivatives.

We recently reported the preparation of several coordination polymers based on carboxylates or bipyridyls by hydrothermal or hydro(solvo)thermal reactions. We decided to adopt the Schiff-base condensation to prepare derivatives of ligands L4−L7 with an even larger N···N separation between the terminal pyridyl groups. Their employment in preparing coordination polymers may provide a high chance of creating novel open-framework structures. We report here the preparation and structures of a novel 3,3‘-bipyridine-type ligand (L, 3,3‘-dimethyl-N 4,N 4‘-bis-pyridin-3-ylmethylene-biphenyl-4,4‘-diamine, py-CHN−(CH3)C6H3−(CH3)C6H3−NCH-py) with the N···N separation of 18.253 Å, and its Zn and Co coordination polymers, [ZnL2(NO3)2] (1) and [CoL1.5(NO3)2] (2). We also report the preparation of guest-containing derivatives of polymer 2, [CoL2(NO3)2]·X (X = benzene (3a) or toluene (3b)).

Their employment in preparing coordination polymers may provide a high chance of creating novel open-framework structures. We report here the preparation and structures of a novel 3,3‘-bipyridine-type ligand (L, 3,3‘-dimethyl-N 4,N 4‘-bis-pyridin-3-ylmethylene-biphenyl-4,4‘-diamine, py-CHN-(CH3)C6H3-(CH3)C6H3-NCH-py) with the N⋅⋅⋅N separation of 18.253 Å, and its Zn and Co coordination polymers, [ZnL2(NO3)2] (1) and [CoL1.5(NO3)2] (2). We also report the preparation of guest-containing derivatives of polymer 2, [CoL2(NO3)2]⋅X (X = benzene (3a) or toluene (3b)).

Synthesis. A long, bis(monodentate) linking ligand C26H22N4 (L), which contains two terminal pyridyl groups with their nitrogen atoms in the 3,3‘-positional orientation, was prepared by the condensation of diamine (o-tolidine dihydrochloride hydrate) and pyridinealdehyde (3-pyridine carboxaldehyde) at room temperature (eq 1). This type of condensation is common and was also employed for the preparation of ligands L4−L7 (Chart ). Ligand L was characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, and X-ray diffraction. The CN stretching frequencies of Schiff bases are known to appear in the range 1680−1603 cm-1, and therefore the absorption band at 1623 cm-1 in the IR spectrum of ligand L can be assigned to the CN bond.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis. A long, bis(monodentate) linking ligand C26H22N4 (L), which contains two terminal pyridyl groups with their nitrogen atoms in the 3,3‘-positional orientation, was prepared by the condensation of diamine (o-tolidine dihydrochloride hydrate) and pyridinealdehyde (3-pyridine carboxaldehyde) at room temperature (eq 1). This type of condensation is common and was also employed for the preparation of ligands L4-L7 (Chart ). Ligand L was characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, and X-ray diffraction. The CN stretching frequencies of Schiff bases are known to appear in the range 1680-1603 cm-1, and therefore the absorption band at 1623 cm-1 in the IR spectrum of ligand L can be assigned to the CN bond.

Zinc and cobalt coordination polymers were prepared from the corresponding metal nitrates and the title ligand in methanol by solvothermal reactions (eqs 2 and 3). Heating zinc(II) nitrate and ligand L in a Teflon-lined reaction vessel at 70 °C for 3 days produced a one-dimensional (1-D) zinc polymer [ZnL(NO3)2] n (1). In the same way, a two-dimensional (2-D) cobalt polymer [CoL1.5(NO3)2] n (2) could be obtained. Both polymers are insoluble in common organic solvents and water, and stable in air. Reactions must be performed under 100 °C to obtain X-ray quality crystals. Those reactions in DMF, THF, or CH3CN did not produce good crystals.

Heating zinc(II) nitrate and ligand L in a Teflon-lined reaction vessel at 70 °C for 3 days produced a one-dimensional (1-D) zinc polymer [ZnL(NO3)2] n  (1). In the same way, a two-dimensional (2-D) cobalt polymer [CoL1.5(NO3)2] n  (2) could be obtained. Both polymers are insoluble in common organic solvents and water, and stable in air. Reactions must be performed under 100 °C to obtain X-ray quality crystals. Those reactions in DMF, THF, or CH3CN did not produce good crystals.

elements.content: With an attempt to prepare guest-containing polymers, we immersed the crystals of polymer 2 in benzene or toluene, but we did not see any sign of entering of these potential guest molecules. Therefore, we decided to prepare polymer 2 in the presence of guest molecules (benzene or toluene). Interestingly, reactions of Co(NO3)2, ligand L, and the guest under the same solvothermal conditions produced polymers with an essentially different framework with a monomer formula of [CoL2(NO3)2]·X (X = benzene (3a) or toluene (3b)), which were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, and X-ray diffraction (3b). Unfortunately, we failed to obtain X-ray quality crystals of 3a, despite several attempts.

Unfortunately, we failed to obtain X-ray quality crystals of 3a, despite several attempts.

elements.content: Structure. The molecular structure of the ligand (L) with the atom-numbering scheme is shown in Figure , in which two pyridyl groups are linked by a diamine moiety (−CHN−(CH3)C6H3−(CH3)C6H3−NCH-) and have their nitrogen atoms at the meta positions (3,3‘). The two terminal pyridyl rings are perfectly parallel to each other (their dihedral angle = 0.0°), which results from their generation by inversion. Consequently, the pyridyl nitrogen atoms are oriented in a trans manner.

elements.content: The N···N separation between the two pyridyl groups in L is 18.253 Å, which is quite a bit longer than that (10.729 Å) in L4 (py-CHN−NCH-py) previously reported by zur Loye and co-workers. In other words, our synthesis has a net effect of inserting a biphenyl unit (-(CH3)C6H3−(CH3)C6H3-) into the two central N−N bonds in the zur Loye's ligand, making the pyridyl N···N separation significantly longer.

In other words, our synthesis has a net effect of inserting a biphenyl unit (-(CH3)C6H3-(CH3)C6H3-) into the two central N-N bonds in the zur Loye's ligand, making the pyridyl N⋅⋅⋅N separation significantly longer.

elements.content: A monomer unit of polymer 1 is shown in Figure . Each Zn metal is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms of two ligands (L) and four nitrate oxygen atoms. The Zn metal lies on the C 2 axis, which accounts for the Z value being 4 instead of 8 (Table ). The coordination sphere of Zn can be described as a pseudo-tetrahedron, if the coordination number of the nitrato ligand is taken to be one. The projection of polymer 1 along the b-axis demonstrates its 1-D chain structure (Figure ), which is formed by the L ligands linking Zn metals in the [101] direction, with the Zn···Zn separation of 20.785 Å and the N···N separation of 18.274 Å. The ligands are coordinated in a cisoid manner, with N1−Zn−N1a = 98.9(2)°. The cisoid ligand form (L‘) in polymer 1 can be generated by rotating one-half ligand L about the central C−C bond, as shown below. However, the terminal pyridyl rings are highly twisted from each other with the dihedral of 58.2(1)°. In addition, the central tolyl rings are also twisted from each other and their dihedral angle is 36.3(2)°. This type of the cisoid coordination of the pyridyl nitrogens of 3,3‘-bipyridine-based ligands is rather unusual and was previously reported for [CuBr(L2)] n .

A monomer unit of polymer 2 is shown in Figure , which shows that the Co(II) metal is seven-coordinate and its coordination sphere consists of three pyridyl nitrogens and four nitrate oxygens. It is well-known that the Co(II) centers in coordination polymers, prepared from cobalt nitrate and N,N‘-bidentate ligands, adopt a {CoN3O4} coordination environment, except for [Co(L5)2(NO3)2] that exhibits a {CoN4O2} core. The Co−N and Co−O bond lengths are 2.134(3)−2.170(3) Å and 2.152(3)−2.396(3) Å, respectively. The Co−O4 bond (2.396(3) Å) is significantly longer than the other three Co−O bonds (2.152(3)−2.256(3) Å), and it is represented as a dotted bond in Figure . In polymer 2, the ligands exhibit a trans coordination of the two pyridyl nitrogens (N−Co−N = 175.9(1)°) with the N···N separation of 18.094 Å.

elements.content: Polymer 2 exhibits the structure of α-arsenic that extends in the [011] direction, which consists of layers of six-membered rings (in terms of Co metals) in the chairlike conformation. Figure shows a projection along the a-axis. Each six-membered unit, which can also be regarded as a quasi-parallelogram, consists of six Co(II) metals and six L ligands to form a large 114-membered (108 ligand atoms and 6 Co metals) ring with dimensions of ca. 40.28 × 20.65 Å (based on Co···Co separations). The most striking structural feature of polymer 2 is not to exhibit interpenetration phenomenon, despite the presence of large repeating rings. Coordination polymers constructed by long organic linkers (or spacers) with large voids generally show interpenetration of their polymeric networks. This type of interpenetration has also occurred for coordination polymers based on the ligands L3−L5.

elements.content: Polymer 3b exhibits an infinite 2-D pattern that extends in the crystallographic ab plane. Figure shows a 1-D channel along the c-axis. Each repeating parallelogram (with corner angles of about 44 and 136°) consists of four Co(II) metals and four L ligands, creating a large 76-membered (72 ligand atoms and 4 Co metals) ring with dimensions of ca. 21.61 × 21.61 Å (based on Co···Co separations). It is worth noting that ligands L6 and L7 reacted with Co(SCN)2 to also give 2-D grid networks [Co(L‘)2(SCN)2] with dimensions of each grid being 11.34 × 11.34 Å20 and 14.95 × 15.27 Å, respectively. Polymer 3b contains one toluene (guest) molecule per monomer unit. Although the toluene molecule itself has no center of symmetry, it lies on the crystallographic center of symmetry, which can account for its extreme structural disorder in the crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: Polymer 3b exhibits an infinite 2-D pattern that extends in the crystallographic ab plane. Figure  shows a 1-D channel along the c-axis. Each repeating parallelogram (with corner angles of about 44 and 136°) consists of four Co(II) metals and  four L ligands, creating a large 76-membered (72 ligand atoms and 4 Co metals) ring with dimensions of ca. 21.61 × 21.61 Å (based on Co⋅⋅⋅Co separations). It is worth noting that ligands L6 and L7 reacted with Co(SCN)2 to also give 2-D grid networks [Co(L‘)2(SCN)2] with dimensions of each grid being 11.34 × 11.34 Å20 and 14.95 × 15.27 Å, respectively. Polymer 3b contains one toluene (guest) molecule per monomer unit. Although the toluene molecule itself has no center of symmetry, it lies on the crystallographic center of symmetry, which can account for its extreme structural disorder in the crystal structure.

elements.content: Barnett and Champness recently published an interesting review article on the structural diversity of building blocks in coordination networks based on metal nitrates (M(NO3)) and dipyridyl ligands (L). According to their review article, the different coordination modes of nitrate anions and dipyridyl functionality can lead to a wide range of different coordination structures, in which the pyridyl ligands can be grouped into three classes:  bis(pyridyl) (A), tris(pyridyl) (B), and tetrakis(pyridyl) (C) modes. In particular, tris(pyridyl)-metal combinations commonly lead to the formation of “T-shaped” connecting units with a general formula ML1.5(NO3)2, which are linked by the bridging dipyridyl ligands to form 1-D, 2-D, and 3-D coordination polymers. The dipyridyl ligand (L) in polymer 2 combines with the cobalt metal to form the “T-joint” units of CoL 1.5(NO3)2, and consequently the structural motif of polymer 2 belongs to the class B, whereas polymer 3b adopts the structure of the class C.

Thermal Gravimetric Analyses. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) reveals that polymer 2 and its guest-containing polymers 3a and 3b have several steps of weight loss (Figure ). All three polymers exhibit a common pattern after 260 °C, that is, an abrupt weight loss between 260 and 305 °C and a steady weight loss after that temperature range. Polymers 3a and 3b exhibit one additional distinct pattern of weight loss (8.1% for 3a; 8.7% for 3b) between 155 and 165 °C, which corresponds to the loss of one guest molecule per formula unit of each polymer (calculated:  7.5% for 3a; 8.7% for 3b).

elements.content: In summary, we prepared a novel, long, 3,3‘-bipyridine-type linking ligand C26H22N4 (L, py-CHN−(CH3)C6H3−(CH3)C6H3−NCH-py) by the Schiff-base condensation, and its zinc and cobalt coordination polymers were prepared from the corresponding metal nitrates and ligand L in methanol under solvothermal conditions. The N···N separation between two pyridyl groups in L is 18.253 Å, which varies from 18.094 to 18.767 Å in its coordination polymers. Ligand L coordinates to the metal via terminal pyridyl nitrogen atoms in a cis (in 1) or trans manner (in 2 and 3b) in these polymers. The imine nitrogen atoms do not bind to the metal in all polymers. The 1-D zinc polymer has the Zn···Zn separation of 20.785 Å, and the ligands are bound in a cisoid manner. Polymer 2 exhibits the structure of α-arsenic, in which each repeating unit (quasi-pallelogram) consists of six Co metals and six L ligands to create a 114-membered ring structure with dimensions of ca. 40.28 × 20.65 Å. Despite its extremely large repeating units, polymer 2 shows no interpenetration phenomenon. We could also prepare guest-containing derivatives of polymer 2, [CoL2(NO3)2]·X (X = benzene (3a) or toluene (3b)).

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All solid chemicals were purified by recrystallization or sublimation, and all solvents were distilled and stored over molecular sieves. IR spectra were recorded with a Nicolet 320 FTIR spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses were performed with EA1110 (CE instrument, Italy) at the Korea Basic Science Institute. TGA analysis was conducted on a TA4000/SDT 2960 instrument.

elements.content: Synthesis of the Ligand (L). Ligand L was synthesized by following the procedure used for the preparation of the L4 ligand. To 3-pyridine carboxaldehyde (nicotinaldehyde, 2.4 mL, 25 mmol) in ethanol (50 mL) was added o-tolidine dihydrochloride hydrate (3,3-dimethylbenzidine dihydrochloride, [-C6H3(CH3)-4-NH2]2·2HCl·H2O, 3.565 g, 12.5 mmol). After the addition of dichloromethane (30 mL) and then two drops of formic acid, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h and then filtered. The resulting yellow crystalline solid was washed with ethanol (3 × 5 mL) and hexane (3 × 5 mL) and dried in air to give the ligand (3.50 g, 8.96 mmol, 72%). mp:  147−149 °C. IR (KBr, cm-1):  1623 (s), 1598 (m), 1568 (m), 1484 (s), 1423 (m), 1228 (m), 1025 (m), 880 (s), 814 (m), 703 (s). Anal. Calcd for C26H22N4:  C, 79.97; H, 5.68; N, 14.35. Found:  C, 79.69; H, 5.90; N, 13.96.

elements.content: Structure Determination. All X-ray data were collected with a Siemens P4 diffractometer equipped with a Mo X-ray tube. No absorption corrections were made for the ligand (L), but empirical absorption corrections were made with ψ-scan data for polymers 1, 2, and 3b. All structures were solved by direct methods. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, except for polymer 3b, in which the cocrystallized toluene guest molecules are extremely disordered, and therefore they were refined isotropically. In addition, one oxygen atom (O3) in the nitrato ligand in polymer 3b exhibited a structural disorder, and the best fit was obtained by considering the oxygen atom to be distributed over two positions with a site occupation fraction of 0.56:0.44. All calculations were carried out with the use of SHELXTL programs.

elements.content: A yellow crystal of ligand L, shaped as a block of approximate dimensions 0.40 × 0.22 × 0.12 mm3, was used for crystal- and intensity-data collection. The unit-cell parameters indicated a triclinic unit cell with the two possible space groups:  P1 and P1̄. A statistical analysis of reflection intensities suggested a centrosymmetric space group, and the structure analysis converged reasonably only in P1̄. All hydrogen atoms were located and refined isotropically.

The unit-cell parameters indicated a triclinic unit cell with the two possible space groups: P1 and P1̄. A statistical analysis of reflection intensities suggested a centrosymmetric space group, and the structure analysis converged reasonably only in P1̄. All hydrogen atoms were located and refined isotropically.

elements.content: A yellow crystal of 1 (a block, 0.26 × 0.16 × 0.12 mm3), a red crystal of 2 (a block, 0.38 × 0.36 × 0.20 mm3), and a yellow crystal of 3b (a block, 0.36 × 0.20 × 0.12 mm3) were used. For all three compounds, unit-cell parameters and systematic absences indicated two possible space groups:  Cc (acentric) and C2/c (centric). The structure analyses converged only in C2/c. All hydrogen atoms in polymer 2 were located and refined isotropically, whereas the remaining hydrogen atoms were generated in ideal positions and refined in a riding mode. Details on crystal data, intensity collection, and refinement details are given in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table .

Thermal Gravimetric Analyses. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) reveals that polymer 2 and its guest-containing polymers 3a and 3b have several steps of weight loss (Figure ). All three polymers exhibit a common pattern after 260 °C, that is, an abrupt weight loss between 260 and 305 °C and a steady weight loss after that temperature range. Polymers 3a and 3b exhibit one additional distinct pattern of weight loss (8.1% for 3a; 8.7% for 3b) between 155 and 165 °C, which corresponds to the loss of one guest molecule per formula unit of each polymer (calculated: 7.5% for 3a; 8.7% for 3b).
